bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to William Dawkins, September 6, 1728

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant William Dawkins, September 6, 1728, to cover some first and second bills of exchange, and to inform him of the Carter's delay in sailing.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to William Dawkins, September 6, 1728

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
Sepr. 6th: 1728
Mr. Wm Dawkins

div1.p:
This Serves only to Enclose to you Some Second
bills of Exchange and three first to wit Martin Brooks on James
Bohannan London for £7"3"7 Franc: Awbry on Mess John
Hyde & Company for £17 Do: Awbrey on Jam. Bohannan £7:16:5
the Seconds are. Robert Carter Junr. on your Self £88 Chs. Fallin
on Capt: Sharp of Whitehaven £10"17"4 Eliza. Nelmes on George
Buck of Biddiford £3. I have a Letter from Capt. Dove of the 16th. of
the month from James River he was put back by an Eastwardly
wind and waiting for a fair one with the Wms:Burgh and Several
other Ships I am
div1.closer:
Yor. humble Servt.
per Capt. Sweet

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Letter book, 1728 August-1731 July, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

[1] Francis (Frank) Awbrey (1690?- 1741) was an active land speculator in the area that became Loudoun County, and was one of the first justices when Prince William County was organized in 1731. He was sheriff of that county in 1739. (McIlwaine. Executive Journals of the Council. . . ., 4[1721-1739]:239, 439; and Harrison. Landmarks. . . .pp. 148, 150, 153-54 ff. )

[2] Isham Randolph was captain of the London ship Williamsburgh in 1725-26, and Charles Rogers commanded her in1727-28. (Admiralty 68/194, ff. 39v, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)
